DataElement.preferredName: Person Malignant Neoplasm Recurrent Disease Disease Progression Diagnosis Malignant Neoplasm Measurable Disease Evaluation Method Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: the type or method of evaluation used to determine information related to the diagnosis of the return of signs and symptoms of cancer after a period of improvement.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Person Malignant Neoplasm Recurrent Disease Disease Progression Diagnosis
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to the diagnosis of the return of signs and symptoms of cancer after a period of improvement.

Property.preferredName: Malignant Neoplasm Recurrent Disease Disease Progression Diagnosis
Property.preferredDefinition: A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues.  Malignant neoplasms usually metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision.  The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas. -- 2004:the return of a sign, symptom, or disease after a remission.:Cancer that continues to grow or spread.:The investigation, analysis and recognition of the presence and nature of disease, condition, or injury from expressed signs and symptoms; also, the scientific determination of any kind; the concise results of such an investigation.

Concepts.definition: A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.
The return of a disease after a period of remission.
A process that manifests as the worsening of a disease over time.

The investigation, analysis and recognition of the presence and nature of disease, condition, or injury from expressed signs and symptoms; also, the scientific determination of any kind; the concise results of such an investigation.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: trial-specific criteria that a patient must meet to be enrolled.

ValueDomain.preferredName: Malignant Neoplasm Measurable Disease Evaluation Method Type
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: the type or method of evaluation used to determine a measurable malignant neoplastic lesion.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An x-ray examination of the chest.

Concepts.definition: An x-ray examination of the chest.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide amazingly clear and detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.

Concepts.definition: Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A method of examining body organs by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis.

Concepts.definition: A method of examining structures within the body by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A type of high-energy radiation.  In low doses, x-rays are used to diagnose diseases by making pictures of the inside of the body.  In high doses, x-rays are used to treat cancer.

Concepts.definition: Ionizing electromagnetic radiation having a wavelength that is shorter than ultraviolet radiation and longer than gamma radiation.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Examination by pressing on the surface of the body to feel the organs or tissues underneath.

Concepts.definition: A method of feeling with the hands during a physical examination. The health care provider touches and feels the patient's body to examine the size, consistency, texture, location and tenderness of an organ or body part.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A method of computed tomography (CT) that uses continuous rotation of the X-ray tube and continuous transport of the patient through the scanning aperture that allows the rapid acquisition of a volume of CT data.  Advantages over conventional CT include: rapid acquisition of a large volume of data within a single breath-hold, thus minimizing respiration artifact and misregistration between slices; the ability to reconstruct images retrospectively at any level within the scanned volume; optimization of intravenous contrast enhancement due to the short scan times; improved multi-planar and 3-D reconstruction; and the potential for radiation dose reduction.  Same as helical computed tomography. (British Journal of Radiology 1994 May;67(797):436-44)

Concepts.definition: A method of computed tomography (CT) that uses continuous rotation of the X-ray tube and continuous transport of the patient through the scanning aperture that allows the rapid acquisition of a volume of CT data.  Advantages over conventional CT include: rapid acquisition of a large volume of data within a single breath-hold, thus minimizing respiration artifact and misregistration between slices; the ability to reconstruct images retrospectively at any level within the scanned volume; optimization of intravenous contrast enhancement due to the short scan times; improved multi-planar and 3-D reconstruction; and the potential for radiation dose reduction.  Same as helical computed tomography. (British Journal of Radiology 1994 May;67(797):436-44)

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

Concepts.definition: Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

ReferenceDocuments.name: How was it established to be
ReferenceDocuments.description: How was it established to be recurrent or persistent for this study?
